item.title: Belgian UFO wave
item.description:
Belgian UFO Wave ðŸ”—

The Belgian UFO wave was a series of sightings of triangular UFOs in Belgium from November 29, 1989, to April 1990.

The Sightings ðŸ”—

This section details the timeline and specifics of the UFO sightings during the Belgian UFO wave. It began in November 1989, with reports describing a large, flat, triangular object flying at low altitude. The peak of the wave occurred on the night of March 30, 1990. On that night, an unknown object was tracked on radar, prompting the Belgian Air Force to send two F-16s to investigate. While the pilots didn’t visually confirm the object, many people claimed to have witnessed it. The Control Reporting Center (CRC) at Glons received initial reports of unusual lights moving towards Thorembais-Gembloux. Traffic Center Control at Semmerzake tracked an object on radar, leading to the scrambling of two F-16 fighters from Beauvechain Air Base. The F-16s attempted nine interceptions, achieving radar lock briefly on three occasions, but these locks were later determined to be on each other. Members of the Wavre gendarmerie reported seeing four lights in a square formation, making jerky movements before disappearing.

Patrick MarÃ©chal Hoax Photograph ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the famous “Petit-Rechain photo,” which depicted a black triangular object with lights. The photo was widely circulated and examined by various organizations, including NASA, the French National Centre for Scientific Research, and the Belgian Royal Military Academy. For two decades, the UFOlogical organization SociÃ©tÃ© belge d’Ã©tude des phÃ©nomÃ¨nes spatiaux (SOBEPS) claimed the photo was genuine. However, in 2011, photographer Patrick MarÃ©chal confessed that it was a hoax. He explained that he had constructed the UFO from a polystyrene triangle with lightbulbs to prank his workmates. Brian Dunning discussed the photograph in his Skeptoid podcast, highlighting it as emblematic of the quality of evidence during the Belgian UFO wave.

Explanations ðŸ”—

This section explores various explanations proposed for the Belgian UFO wave. In 1992, Marc Hallet criticized SOBEPS, arguing that the wave was a mass delusion fueled by misinformation. Pierre Magain and Marc Remy suggested that the phenomenon would be better studied by human scientists than physicists. Renaud Leclet and co. proposed that some sightings could be explained by helicopters, with the lack of noise attributed to environmental factors. Jean-Michel Abrassart argued that the beginning of the wave aligns with the psychosocial hypothesis. Auguste Meessen defended the unexplained nature of the wave, prompting rebuttals from Roger Paquay and Jean-Michel Abrassart. Brian Dunning discussed the F-16 chase, noting that radar locks were likely on each other due to atmospheric interference (Bragg scattering). He concludes that the sightings were a psychosocial phenomenon, explaining the lack of substantial evidence.

item.title: UFO sightings in Belgium
item.description:
UFO Sightings in Belgium ðŸ”—

This article documents alleged UFO sightings in Belgium, focusing primarily on the significant wave of sightings between 1989 and 1990.

1989-1990 ðŸ”—

This section highlights the Belgian UFO wave, a period of intense UFO activity. The main feature of this wave was the frequent reports of triangular UFOs observed across the country. These objects were even pursued by Belgian Air Force F-16 fighter jets, and some photographs were taken. One speculative explanation suggested these sightings might have been misidentified stealth aircraft, specifically the F-117 Nighthawk, using Belgian highways for navigation.

1990-03-30 ðŸ”—

This section details a specific mass sighting event that occurred on March 30, 1990, in Ans, Wallonia. Numerous witnesses reported seeing large, silent, low-flying black triangles. These objects were tracked by multiple NATO radar systems and intercepted by jet fighters. The Belgian military investigated the incident, and photographic evidence is said to exist. A close encounter was also reported during this event.
